moves.1. d4: White opens with the Queen's pawn opening. My favorite with White as well
moves.1... d5: I'm a strict believer that 1...d5 is better than the popular 1...Nf6
moves.2. c4: Queen's Gambit. The most logical following of the first move
moves.2... e6: Queen's gambit declined. I like playing this from both sides
moves.3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e3: It probably isn't best to lock the bishop in this position as it belongs on g5.
moves.4... Bb4: Black pins the Knight. I felt that I don't need to stick my bishop on e7 as White has no intentions of placing the Bishop on g5.
moves.5... O-O 6. Nf3 b6: I like to Fianchetto the Bishop in the QGD.
moves.7. Be2: I put the Bishop on d3 but it's a matter of preference. I just feel that White hasn't really challenged Black with this opening
moves.7... Bb7 8. O-O Nbd7: ? The Knight can certainly be placed on d7 but not in this situation
moves.9. Qc2: ? A mistake in return. White misses 9. Nxd5! 9...Nxd5 is forced (9...Bxd2 10. Nxf6+ followed by 11. Qxd2) 10. cxd5 Bxd2 11.dxe6 Bxe3 12. exf7+ Rxf7 13. fxe3 wins a pawn
moves.9... Bxc3 10. Bxc3 Ne4: The Knight goes to its most active post
moves.12. Bb2 Rc8: I feel Black has least equalized here.
moves.13. Bd3: Challenging the Knight and going where it probably should've gone on move 7
moves.13... dxc4: Opening up some lines for my Bishop on b7
moves.14. bxc4 c5: Theoretical break for the Black side.
moves.15. Nd2: The Knight must now be moved
moves.17. Rfe1 cxd4 18. exd4: White now has "hanging pawns" on c4 and d4. These pawns are certainly not bad but White should not trade down because their weakness will be exposed
moves.18... Qd6: Connecting the rooks. 18...Qxd4? would allow 19. Bxh7+!
moves.19. a4: White threatens 20. a5 which would open a line for his rook and give Black an isolated pawn on the Queenside
moves.19... a5: I need not worry about the outpost on b5 because White does not have a Knight
moves.20. Ba3 Qd7 21. Rab1: White wants to trade which is favorable for Black. This will expose the hanging pawns a little more
moves.21... Qxa4 22. Rxb6 Qxa3 23. Rxb7 Red8: Centralizing the other rook and giving it something to look forward to. Notice how both my rooks are aimed at the pawns.
moves.24. Rbb1 Qd6: The Queen steps back and now 25...Qxd6 becomes a legitimate threat
moves.25. Red1: Still wanting to use the same trap
moves.25... Kh8: Finally getting rid of the annoying Bxh7+ nonsense
moves.26. Qxa5: Black should not worry because he will win back the d4 pawn
moves.27. c5: ?! White now isolates the d4 pawn AND trades down, further exposing it. This changes the tide of the game
moves.27... Rxa5 28. cxd6 Rd5: White still has a trap! 28...Rxd6?? 29. Rb8+ with mate to follow
moves.29. Bc4 Rd5xd6 30. Rb7 Kg8: That d4 pawn sticks his tounge out and says "Na-na-na-boo-boo you can't take me!" which still aggravates Black. The King defends the f7 pawn from attack
moves.31. f3 g6: Finally! No more traps can be set by White. The d4 pawn's triumphant teasing will end
moves.32. Kf2 Rd6xd4 33. Rxd4 Rxd4: This is far from a winning endgame but Black has all the winning chances
moves.34. Be2 Kg7 35. Ke3 Ra4: I don't want the king to make it past the 3rd rank
moves.36. g4: ? Honestly it's hard to suggest an alternative but this makes Black's life so much easier
moves.37. Kf2 Ra2: Pin! White must respond to the threat of 38...Nc3, winning the Bishop
moves.39. Kf2: 39. Ke1 Nc2+ followed by 40...Nd4 will still win a pawn
moves.39... Nd1+ 40. Ke1 Nc3: White is now forced to move the Bishop
moves.41. Bc4 Rxh2: Black can probably win this endgame if he used good technique
